Dear SALLY SMITH:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
Section (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
Description shall complete a written report that includes all of the following
information:
1

(e) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The special investigation findings do not match the information
contained in the report as well as documentation and evidence
obtained by the agency.
Investigation DHS worker was interviewed via Teams on July 17, 2023. She
stated the incident was recorded on video surveillance at the
store. She does not have a copy of the video. She stated the file
was too large to view in her office, so she viewed it at the law
enforcement office. Youth A was made to do a wall sit and was
alone against the wall for approximately 2 and a half minutes,
however, he was made to continue, and another child walked over
and held his feet so he couldn’t sit down. DHS worker stated
Youth A was against the wall for a total of approximately 30
minutes. She stated when Youth A was interviewed, he disclosed
that wall sits are a regularly used method of punishment.
Licensing supervisor (LS) was interviewed via telephone on
July 19, 2023. LS stated due to the nature of the investigation she
met with the Licensing worker on a regular basis and reviewed the
videos and documentation. She stated in reviewing the video clips
taken from Walmart surveillance, Youth A was made to do wall
sits for approximately 6 minutes total with a few breaks. The
longest singular wall sit was 2 and a half minutes. LS stated she
and the licensing worker discussed the use of wall sits with Youth
A’s therapist, school staff, and foster care. All were aware wall sits
were utilized as a discipline method in the home, and it posted in
writing in the caregiver’s house. LS stated Youth A’s therapist
advised it was an appropriate method of discipline for him due to
his behaviors. The agency assessed wall sits and determined it
did not meet the definition of corporal punishment. LS stated the
video footage does not have audio but appears to show Youth B
kicking and screaming. Caregiver covers Youth B’s mouth several
times and then slapped him in the mouth. She stated the agency
is not able to tell Caregiver how to parent and discipline her own
child.
Documents reviewed:
• April 4, 2023, Special investigation report completed by
Ennis for Children-Port Huron: Report documents
Caregiver’s use of wall sits as a form of discipline for Youth
A both during the incident at Walmart and as a regular
occurrence in the home. In addition, report documents
review of video footage from Walmart on January 2, 2023.
Report describes video shows Caregiver “smack” Youth B
2

in the mouth. Report concludes Caregiver is cited for rule
9403 (1)(d)(i). The conclusion for the citation states
Caregiver’s use of walls sits violated the behavior
management plan for Youth A. There was no citation
issued for Caregiver’s actions on January 2, 2023, in
Walmart when she smacked Youth B in the mouth.
• January 24, 2023, DHS report: Youth A was interviewed
and reported he has to do wall sits when he is disciplined.
He has to stay in that position until he’s told he can move,
or he stops crying. He disclosed his legs would really hurt
during wall sits (p. 7). Caregiver admitted she smacked
Youth B on the mouth. She admitted to the allegations but
minimized them (p. 5). Caregiver utilizes wall sits with
Youth A. She reports she does this for 30-45 seconds.
Another child was interviewed and stated that Youth A was
reporting his legs hurt during wall sits (p. 18). Another child
was interviewed and stated that Youth A was reporting his
legs hurt during wall sits. Youth A started to sit down so
Caregiver instructed her to stand on his foot so he couldn’t
sit down (p. 19).
• Behavior management policy: Agency’s internal behavior
management policy states any kind of punishment inflicted
on the body is prohibited. In addition, agency’s policy states
physical discipline of foster parents’ own children is to
occur when foster children are not present.
Video reviewed:
• Video footage of 12/29/2022 from Walmart was
reviewed on July 28, 2023.
10:37pm Caregiver walks Youth A toward front wall.
Caregiver has Youth A do a wall sit while she stands on his
feet angled so that she’s looking away from him. He
appears to struggle to maintain the wall sit. Caregiver
pushes his shoulder down on 6 different occasions so that
he is sitting lower on the wall. After a few minutes
Caregiver walks away and starts to check out. Youth girl
walks over and stands on his feet. At 10:42 Youth A sits
down, and the little girl walks toward the checkout. Youth A
stands up for a few minutes and then sits down again. They
leave the store at 10:51pm.
• Video footage of 1/2/203 from Walmart was reviewed on
July 28, 2023.
Caregiver, Youth A and Youth B walk up to checkout at
8:45pm. Youth B is sitting in the child seat of the cart. His
legs are visibly moving as if he is kicking. Caregiver puts
3

her hand over his mouth approximately 8 times. At 8:50pm
Caregiver is seen slapping his mouth with her right hand.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as the agency findings in
the special investigation completed do not match the information
contained in the report, as well as video footage and a DHS
report. Video footage, DHS report and special investigation report
completed by the agency documents Caregiver put her hand over
Youth B’s mouth approximately 8 times within a 10-minute period
while at Walmart. She slapped Youth B in the mouth when he
continued to kick and scream. The agency did not cite Caregiver
for rule 9201 (j).
In addition, video footage from Walmart shows Youth A was made
to complete wall sits as a form of punishment inflicted on the body.
Agency cited foster parent for 9403 (1)(d)(i) stating the use of wall
sits violated Youth A’s case plan. However, the agency did not cite
the Caregiver for violating licensing rule 313 (3)(a) that specifically
addresses this type of behavior management is prohibited as well
as the agency’s behavior management policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Rule Code & Public Act 116, 722.120 (10) (3) Confidentiality A licensee shall
Section keep the records the department prescribes regarding each child
Description in its control and care and shall report to the department, when
requested, the facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department. Except as
otherwise provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and their
parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure of this
information shall be properly safeguarded by the child care
organization, the department, and any other entity in possession
of the information. Records that are confidential under this section
are available to both of the following:
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency documented CPS MIC involvement in their completed
special investigation.
Investigation Documents Reviewed:
• Special investigation report dated April 4, 2023:
The special investigation report references “CPS” and
“MIC” approximately three times. The report states that the
CPS-MIC Investigation will be opened as a Category II with
a High-Risk Level and transferred to local for monitoring.
4

Analysis The agency was found in noncompliance. In reviewing the special
investigation report completed by the agency it was noted the
report references “CPS” and “MIC”.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
